hook.text: Japan recognized Bitcoin as legal property in 2017 and created a licensing system for crypto exchanges.

buildup.text: After the Mt. Gox disaster, Japan built strict exchange regulations requiring reserves, audits, and customer protections.

discovery.text: Licensed exchanges must segregate customer funds and maintain cold storage. Japan learned from Mt. Gox's failures.

twist.text: Japan's strict rules caused some exchanges to leave. Innovation sometimes moves to countries with lighter regulation.

climax.text: Japan proves that early, clear regulation can work. Exchanges are safer, even if fewer companies choose to operate there.

punchline.text: Japan lost Mt. Gox. It built the strongest exchange rules in the world because of it.

quiz.question: How did the Mt. Gox hack influence Japan's crypto regulation?
options: Japan created strict exchange licensing with fund segregation and audits
